translations.cfg_alert_0: Synchronous + No support: real-time sessions are difficult to manage without the trainer present to facilitate and moderate.
translations.cfg_alert_1: Collaborative + Asynchronous: deferred-time collaboration requires very structured tools and instructions to coordinate group work.
translations.cfg_alert_2: Production + No support: learners who must produce their own resources often need guidance and feedback.
translations.cfg_alert_3: Synchronous + Production + Collaborative + No support: very demanding configuration that requires a high level of autonomy and skills from learners.
translations.cfg_alert_4: Synchronous + Production + Collaborative (with support): this combination requires significant real-time coordination.
translations.cfg_alert_5: Large group + Strong support: individualized support becomes difficult with a large number of participants.
translations.cfg_alert_6: Distance + Synchronous: synchronous distance sessions require reliable tools and a good connection.
translations.cfg_alert_7: Distance + Large group + No support: learners can easily feel isolated and lost.
translations.cfg_alert_8: Distance + Collaborative: distance collaboration requires specific tools and rigorous organization.
translations.cfg_alert_9: Large group + Collaborative: organizing collaborative work with a large number of participants requires strong structuring.
translations.cfg_alert_10: Large group + Production: supporting resource production by a large group is demanding.
translations.cfg_alert_11: In-person + Asynchronous: this combination is inconsistent. If learners are present, prioritize synchronous interactions.

translations.persona_help_body:
1. What is a persona?
A persona is a fictional but realistic profile representing a segment of your target audience. It synthesizes data from observations, interviews or analyses to guide the design of adapted training programs.

2. How many personas to create?
Generally, 3 to 5 personas are enough to cover your audience's diversity. A single persona risks over-generalizing; beyond 7, complexity becomes hard to manage.

3. The 6 essential sections

  • Identity & Image: Name, avatar and key quote.
  • Demographics: Age, gender, education, position.
  • Work Context: Environment, time, constraints.
  • Preferences: Attitude, digital comfort, formats.
  • Gaps & Motivation: Level, barriers, benefits.
  • Learning Moments: When and how.

4. Usage
Fill in each section per persona, navigate between tabs, then export as JSON or Markdown.

translations.teacher_help_body:
1. Purpose
This canvas is used to describe a typical profile (persona) in order to design training programs that are truly adapted to needs, motivations, constraints and work contexts.

2. Toggle views (top of page)
Two switches control the display:

  • Basic / Advanced: enables advanced options to specify particular contexts (geography, infrastructure, specific challenges, etc.).
  • Suggestions: shows (or hides) the checkbox lists in all sections.

3. Fill in the persona

  • Free text: describe qualitative elements.
  • Suggestions: enable the toggle to display options, then check what applies.

4. Import & Export
The IMPORT & EXPORT section groups sharing and saving actions.

Note
This tool is an unofficial prototype.

translations.analysis_help_body:
1. What is a needs analysis?
A needs analysis is the first step in any instructional design process. It determines whether training is the appropriate response to a performance problem and, if so, defines its content and format.

2. The 8 sections

  • Clarification: understand and reformulate the initial request.
  • Organizational need: link the request to a measurable objective.
  • Desired performance: describe what learners should be able to do.
  • Current performance: document the current state and gap.
  • Task analysis: break down the work into concrete tasks.
  • Learner profile: understand the target audience.
  • Influencing factors: identify barriers and enablers.
  • Constraints: frame the project (budget, timeline, format).

3. Reference
Carliner, S. (2015). Training Design Basics (2nd ed.). ATD Press.
